replies.content: Triglycerides will go down if you stick to the diet. üòÅ
Listen to Dr Paul mason and Dr Ken Berry on the topic of cholesterol. Good youtube info on the topic and on statins
Looks good but I'm no expert. Similar to my numbers though, everything high but the triglycerides which is the only one to worry about from what I've heard.

Tbh, look at trigs/HDL. Less than 1 is ideal ( they were better last year imo). Here is the thing tho, if your fasting was not within their range, then the numbers are out. If he is worried, do another test. The numbers change ( Dave Feldman showed he‚Ä¶ See more

replies.reply_by: Mick Camilleri I fast for 12 hours.
replies.content: I have to go back in a few weeks for another test
Lisa Jules that should be in the sweet spot but try a shorter time. They may have typed it in wrong as well
Also they must look at cholesterol particle size, not just the levels. Big fluffy particles are good and small sneaky ones are bad.

You wouldn't be the first that has been told that. Funny thing is that doctors don't tell you that people that die from heart disease/attacks usually have low cholesterol levels not high levels....and the older you are it is actually better to have higher cholesterol!
Julie Korte also alzheimers and dementia
Ashley Thorei yes sadly....so much false information is given to people these days üòû
I wouldn't even bother worrying about cholesterol levels before you first look at your inflammation markers.
No worries mate
Trig hdl ratio ok
Reasearch by dave feldman is very interesting
Nothing to worry about. Lipid panels are a waste of time, no evidence to say they cause any disease

Well we are all going to pop our clogs one day.. however you will have good health in the meantime

If you're concerned, get a CAC test, coronary arterial calcification score. It's by far the best indicator.
LDL can be high, but if CAC is low, you're completely fine.‚Ä¶ See more
Elijah Shervey Triglycerides need to 1 or under, if not there might be some concern about the LDL number.
